publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-3906<> Bill Butler: Sectarianism in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the launch of the Scottish Executive’s 18-point Action Plan on Tackling Sectarianism which will see the Executive support and expand the range of local and national initiatives that emerged from the National Summit on Sectarianism, held in February 2005; recognises that sectarianism is a problem throughout Scotland and that it must be confronted; realises the importance of supporting community-based projects, such as Glasgow City Council’s Sense over Sectarianism campaign and the twinning of denominational and non-denominational schools, in challenging sectarian attitudes and improving young people’s understanding of each others’ cultural identities, and commends the efforts of the Executive, local authorities, charities such as Nil By Mouth, churches and community groups in highlighting the problems of bigotry and sectarianism which exist within communities and workplaces throughout Scotland. Supported by: Jackie Baillie*, Trish Godman*

S2M-3906<> Sectarianism in Scotland (lodged on 31 January 2006) Chris Ballance*, Cathie Craigie*, Margaret Jamieson*, Dr Sylvia Jackson*, Patrick Harvie*, Marlyn Glen*, Mr Kenneth Macintosh*, Mrs Mary Mulligan*

S2M-3906*#* Bill Butler: Sectarianism in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the launch of the Scottish Executive’s 18-point Action Plan on Tackling Sectarianism which will see the Executive support and expand the range of local and national initiatives that emerged from the National Summit on Sectarianism, held in February 2005; recognises that sectarianism is a problem throughout Scotland and that it must be confronted; realises the importance of supporting community-based projects, such as Glasgow City Council’s Sense over Sectarianism campaign and the twinning of denominational and non-denominational schools, in challenging sectarian attitudes and improving young people’s understanding of each others’ cultural identities, and commends the efforts of the Executive, local authorities, charities such as Nil By Mouth, churches and community groups in highlighting the problems of bigotry and sectarianism which exist within communities and workplaces throughout Scotland. Supported by: Murray Tosh*, Ms Sandra White*, Mr Jamie Stone*, Donald Gorrie*, Marilyn Livingstone*, Mr Charlie Gordon*, Shiona Baird*, Christine Grahame*, Janis Hughes*

S2M-3906# Bill Butler: Sectarianism in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the launch of the Scottish Executive’s 18-point Action Plan on Tackling Sectarianism which will see the Executive support and expand the range of local and national initiatives that emerged from the National Summit on Sectarianism, held in February 2005; recognises that sectarianism is a problem throughout Scotland and that it must be confronted; realises the importance of supporting community-based projects, such as Glasgow City Council’s Sense over Sectarianism campaign and the twinning of denominational and non-denominational schools, in challenging sectarian attitudes and improving young people’s understanding of each others’ cultural identities, and commends the efforts of the Executive, local authorities, charities such as Nil By Mouth, churches and community groups in highlighting the problems of bigotry and sectarianism which exist within communities and workplaces throughout Scotland. Supported by: Jackie Baillie, Trish Godman, Chris Ballance, Cathie Craigie, Margaret Jamieson, Dr Sylvia Jackson, Patrick Harvie, Marlyn Glen, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Mrs Mary Mulligan, Murray Tosh, Ms Sandra White, Mr Jamie Stone, Donald Gorrie, Marilyn Livingstone, Mr Charlie Gordon, Shiona Baird, Christine Grahame, Janis Hughes, Dennis Canavan*

S2M-3906# Bill Butler: Sectarianism in Scotland—That the Parliament welcomes the launch of the Scottish Executive’s 18-point Action Plan on Tackling Sectarianism which will see the Executive support and expand the range of local and national initiatives that emerged from the National Summit on Sectarianism, held in February 2005; recognises that sectarianism is a problem throughout Scotland and that it must be confronted; realises the importance of supporting community-based projects, such as Glasgow City Council’s Sense over Sectarianism campaign and the twinning of denominational and non-denominational schools, in challenging sectarian attitudes and improving young people’s understanding of each others’ cultural identities, and commends the efforts of the Executive, local authorities, charities such as Nil By Mouth, churches and community groups in highlighting the problems of bigotry and sectarianism which exist within communities and workplaces throughout Scotland. Supported by: Jackie Baillie, Trish Godman, Chris Ballance, Cathie Craigie, Margaret Jamieson, Dr Sylvia Jackson, Patrick Harvie, Marlyn Glen, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Mrs Mary Mulligan, Murray Tosh, Ms Sandra White, Mr Jamie Stone, Donald Gorrie, Marilyn Livingstone, Mr Charlie Gordon, Shiona Baird, Christine Grahame, Janis Hughes, Dennis Canavan, Scott Barrie, Nora Radcliffe, John Swinburne, Irene Oldfather, Robin Harper, Cathy Peattie, Elaine Smith, Rob Gibson, Christine May, Ms Rosemary Byrne, Mark Ballard, Sarah Boyack, Bristow Muldoon, Mr Jim Wallace, Maureen Macmillan, John Home Robertson, Pauline McNeill, Dr Jean Turner, Mr Frank McAveety, Mr Adam Ingram, Roseanna Cunningham Motions and amendments which have attracted additional support
